title: MiniMax-Speech: Intrinsic Zero-Shot Text-to-Speech with a Learnable Speaker Encoder
author: MiniMax Team, ..., Haohe Liu (University of Surrey)
relevance_why: The paper introduces significant advancements in text-to-speech synthesis, particularly with zero-shot voice cloning, which can be applied to enhance audio generation techniques in Haohe's research.
background: The task involves generating high-fidelity speech from text while preserving the unique voice characteristics of a target speaker using minimal voice data.
contribution: The paper introduces MiniMax-Speech, a TTS model that enables high-quality zero-shot voice cloning without transcription, achieving state-of-the-art results in both fidelity and speaker similarity across multiple languages.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in voice cloning typically require both reference audio and corresponding text, which can lead to mismatches affecting output quality.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves voice cloning fidelity by using a learnable speaker encoder that extracts vocal features from untranscribed audio, enabling robust zero-shot synthesis.

key_innovation: The architecture introduces a learnable speaker encoder integrated with an autoregressive Transformer, allowing high-quality speech generation without needing transcription.
real_world_impact: This advancement can significantly improve applications such as conversational AI, voice assistants, and personalized audio content generation, thereby enhancing user experiences in various domains.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention limitations.

new_terms.zero-shot: **Zero-shot learning** refers to a model's ability to generalize for tasks it has not explicitly been trained on, which is a significant characteristic of the proposed TTS system.
new_terms.autoregressive: **Autoregressive models** are a class of models that predict future values based on previously observed values, commonly used in time-series predictions.
